title: Nicomachean Ethics
subtitle: The Science of Human Flourishing
summary: Aristotle's comprehensive work on ethics, exploring the nature of virtue, happiness, and the good life through practical wisdom.
keyConceptExplanation: Human flourishing achieved through virtuous activity in accordance with reason

sections.title: The Highest Good
sections.content: All human activities aim at some good, but the ultimate end is eudaimonia - not mere pleasure or honor, but excellent activity of the rational soul over a complete life.

sections.title: The Doctrine of the Mean
sections.content: Moral virtue is a mean state between two vices - one of excess and one of deficiency. Courage lies between cowardice and rashness, generosity between stinginess and wastefulness.

sections.title: Intellectual vs Moral Virtue
sections.content: Moral virtues (courage, temperance) are acquired through habit. Intellectual virtues (wisdom, understanding) are acquired through teaching. Practical wisdom (phronesis) bridges both.

sections.title: Friendship and Community
sections.content: Friendship is essential for the good life. The highest form is between virtuous individuals who wish each other well for their own sake. The friend is 'another self.'

funFacts: Named after Aristotle's son Nicomachus, who may have edited it
Basis for modern virtue ethics movement
Influenced Thomas Aquinas and medieval Christian ethics
The 'golden mean' concept appears in many world philosophies

keyPrinciples.explanation: We become just by doing just acts, brave by doing brave acts - virtue requires practice
The good for anything depends on its function - for humans, this is rational activity
We are responsible for voluntary actions done with knowledge and choice

title: Politics
subtitle: The Science of the Polis
summary: Aristotle's analysis of political communities, constitutions, and the ideal state, based on empirical study of 158 Greek constitutions.
keyConcept: Man is by nature a political animal
keyConceptExplanation: Humans achieve their full potential only within the political community (polis)

sections.title: The Natural Polis
sections.content: The state develops naturally from households to villages to city-states. It exists for the sake of the good life, not mere survival.

sections.title: Classification of Governments
sections.content: Good forms: Monarchy (rule by one), Aristocracy (rule by few), Polity (rule by many). Corrupt forms: Tyranny, Oligarchy, Democracy.

sections.title: The Ideal State
sections.content: The best state has a large middle class for stability, public education, and citizens who can both rule and be ruled. It balances freedom and order.

sections.title: Revolution and Stability
sections.content: Constitutions fail when justice is violated. The best protection is education that matches the constitution and prevents extreme inequality.

funFacts: Based on study of 158 actual constitutions - only Athens' survives
Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great in politics
His analysis of revolution influenced Machiavelli
Defended slavery as 'natural' - a major ethical flaw

keyPrinciples.explanation: The state exists for the sake of the good life, not just life
The best government combines elements of different systems
Law should rule rather than any individual

title: Metaphysics
subtitle: First Philosophy
summary: Aristotle's investigation into being as being, substance, causality, and the fundamental principles of reality.
keyConcept: The science of being qua being
keyConceptExplanation: The study of existence itself, not just particular aspects of reality

sections.title: The Four Causes
sections.content: To understand anything, we must know its: Material cause (what it's made of), Formal cause (its essence), Efficient cause (what made it), Final cause (its purpose).

sections.title: Substance and Accident
sections.content: Substance is what exists independently (this man, this horse). Accidents are properties that depend on substance (white, tall).

sections.title: Potentiality and Actuality
sections.content: Everything contains potentiality (what it can become) and actuality (what it currently is). Actuality is prior to potentiality.

sections.title: The Unmoved Mover
sections.content: There must be a first cause - eternal, immaterial, purely actual - that moves everything as a final cause, by being an object of thought and desire.

funFacts: Title means 'after the Physics' - the order it was placed in his works
Called 'first philosophy' by Aristotle himself
Influenced medieval theology and the concept of God
One of the most difficult and debated texts in Western philosophy

keyPrinciples.explanation: All physical objects are compounds of matter (hyle) and form (morphe)
Actuality is prior to potentiality in definition, time, and substance
The same attribute cannot belong and not belong to the same subject at the same time

title: Physics
subtitle: The Science of Nature
summary: Aristotle's foundational work on natural philosophy, exploring motion, change, time, and the principles of the physical world.
keyConcept: Nature is a principle of motion and change
keyConceptExplanation: Natural objects have within themselves principles of motion and rest

sections.title: The Principles of Change
sections.content: All change involves three principles: substratum (what persists), form (what is gained), and privation (what is lost).

sections.title: The Four Causes in Nature
sections.content: Natural phenomena are explained by material, formal, efficient, and final causes. Nature acts for ends - 'nature does nothing in vain.'

sections.title: Motion and Time
sections.content: Motion is the actuality of what exists potentially. Time is the number of motion in respect of before and after.

sections.title: Teleology in Nature
sections.content: Everything in nature has a purpose. The acorn's telos is to become an oak tree. Final causes are essential for understanding nature.

funFacts: Dominant physics until Galileo and Newton 2000 years later
His theories were wrong but methodologically sophisticated
Rejected atomism and the void
His concept of natural place influenced medieval cosmology

keyPrinciples.explanation: Elements move toward their natural places: earth down, fire up
Rejected atoms - matter is infinitely divisible in theory
A vacuum is impossible - nature abhors a void

title: Poetics
subtitle: The Theory of Tragedy
summary: Aristotle's analysis of poetry and drama, defining the elements of tragedy and explaining its psychological impact.
keyConceptExplanation: The purification or purgation of emotions of pity and fear through dramatic representation

sections.title: Art as Imitation
sections.content: Poetry is imitation (mimesis) of human action. It represents universal truths, making it more philosophical than history.

sections.title: The Six Elements of Tragedy
sections.content: Plot (mythos) - the soul of tragedy, Character (ethos), Thought (dianoia), Diction (lexis), Song (melos), Spectacle (opsis).

sections.title: The Perfect Tragedy
sections.content: Involves a good man falling from happiness to misery through hamartia (error), producing pity and fear leading to catharsis.

sections.title: Unity and Probability
sections.content: Plot should have unity of action - one complete action with beginning, middle, end. Events should follow probably or necessarily.

funFacts: Only part on tragedy survives - comedy section is lost
Influenced Renaissance drama and Shakespeare
The 'three unities' (action, time, place) were Renaissance additions
Hamartia is often misunderstood as 'tragic flaw' rather than 'error'

keyPrinciples.explanation: Plot is the soul of tragedy - characters exist for the sake of action
Best plots involve peripeteia (reversal) and anagnorisis (recognition)
Poetry deals with what may happen - the universal - unlike history's particulars

title: On the Soul (De Anima)
subtitle: The Science of Life
summary: Aristotle's investigation into the nature of the soul as the form and actuality of living bodies.
keyConcept: The soul is the first actuality of a natural body having life potentially
keyConceptExplanation: The soul is what makes a living body actually alive - it's the form of the body

sections.title: Hylomorphism
sections.content: The soul is to the body as form is to matter. They are inseparable - the soul is not a separate substance trapped in the body.

sections.title: Hierarchy of Souls
sections.content: Nutritive soul (plants - growth/nutrition), Perceptive soul (animals - adds perception), Rational soul (humans - adds reason).

sections.title: Perception and Thought
sections.content: Perception receives the form of objects without their matter. Mind has passive intellect (receives forms) and active intellect (makes them intelligible).

sections.title: The Active Intellect
sections.content: The active intellect (nous poietikos) is immortal and divine - it makes all things intelligible and is separable from the body.

funFacts: Foundation for philosophy of mind for 2000 years
His view conflicted with Christian doctrine of immortal soul
Active intellect concept heavily debated in medieval philosophy
Influenced cognitive science and theories of consciousness

keyPrinciples.explanation: Soul and body are not separate substances but form and matter of one being
Higher souls include capacities of lower ones
Mind becomes what it thinks - takes on form of objects

title: Rhetoric
subtitle: The Art of Persuasion
summary: Aristotle's systematic analysis of persuasive speech as essential for civic life and discovering truth.
keyConceptExplanation: Rhetoric is the faculty of discovering in any case the available means of persuasion

sections.title: Three Modes of Persuasion
sections.content: Ethos (character of speaker), Pathos (emotional appeal to audience), Logos (logical argument). Ethos is most important.

sections.title: The Enthymeme
sections.content: The rhetorical syllogism - often with one premise left unstated, relying on audience's shared knowledge and values.

sections.title: Three Genres of Oratory
sections.content: Deliberative (future action - political), Forensic (past events - legal), Epideictic (present - ceremonial praise/blame).

sections.title: Virtue of Style
sections.content: Style should be clear, appropriate, and avoid meanness or excess. Metaphor is the mark of genius.

funFacts: First systematic rhetoric text - still taught today
Defended rhetoric against Plato's attack in Gorgias
Ethos, pathos, logos used in advertising and politics
Based on analysis of actual Athenian speeches

keyPrinciples.explanation: Rhetoric can be used for good or ill - it's a tool, not inherently deceptive
Effective persuasion requires understanding the audience's values and emotions
Rhetoric deals with probable truth, not scientific demonstration

title: Categories
subtitle: The Foundation of Logic
summary: Aristotle's analysis of the basic types of being and the structure of predication.
keyConcept: Substance is that which is neither predicable of a subject nor present in a subject
keyConceptExplanation: Primary substance is the fundamental reality - individual things that exist independently

sections.title: The Ten Categories
sections.content: Substance, Quantity, Quality, Relation, Place, Time, Position, State, Action, Affection. These are the ways we can talk about what exists.

sections.title: Primary vs Secondary Substance
sections.content: Primary substance: individual things (this man, this horse). Secondary substance: species and genera (man, animal).

sections.title: Predication Relations
sections.content: Things can be said OF a subject (universals) or be IN a subject (particular accidents). Only primary substances are neither.

sections.title: The Fourfold Division
sections.content: Universal and particular, substance and accident create four combinations defining how things exist and are predicated.

funFacts: First work in Aristotle's Organon (logical works)
Foundation for Western logic for 2000 years
Categories influenced medieval philosophy and linguistics
Some categories seem arbitrary - later philosophers revised the list

keyPrinciples.explanation: All other categories depend on substance for their existence
Different ways things can be said of subjects reveal their ontological status
Some predicates express what a thing is, others how it is qualified

title: Posterior Analytics
subtitle: The Theory of Scientific Knowledge
summary: Aristotle's analysis of scientific demonstration and how we gain certain knowledge from first principles.
keyConcept: Scientific knowledge is knowledge through demonstration
keyConceptExplanation: We know something scientifically when we know its cause and that it cannot be otherwise

sections.title: The Structure of Demonstration
sections.content: Scientific demonstration is a syllogism from premises that are true, primary, immediate, better known than and prior to the conclusion.

sections.title: First Principles
sections.content: All knowledge rests on indemonstrable first principles (archai) grasped by understanding (nous), not demonstration.

sections.title: The Four Types of Inquiry
sections.content: That it is, Why it is, If it is, What it is. Complete scientific knowledge answers all four.

sections.title: Definition and Essence
sections.content: Scientific knowledge requires knowing the essence - what makes something what it is. Definitions express essences.

funFacts: Provided the model for Euclidean geometry
Influenced the ideal of science as deductive system
His model doesn't perfectly fit modern empirical science
The concept of 'nous' for grasping first principles remains mysterious

keyPrinciples.explanation: Scientific knowledge comes through syllogisms showing necessary connections
We know something when we know why it must be so
Demonstration must start from premises that don't need demonstration

title: Prior Analytics
subtitle: The Invention of Formal Logic
summary: Aristotle's creation of syllogistic logic - the first formal system of deductive reasoning.
keyConceptExplanation: A discourse in which, certain things being stated, something other than what is stated follows of necessity

sections.title: The Syllogistic Figures
sections.content: Three figures based on position of middle term. First figure: Barbara, Celarent, etc. Second and third figures can be reduced to first.

sections.title: Modal Logic
sections.content: Extended syllogistic to include necessity and possibility. Developed rules for modal syllogisms.

sections.title: Conversion Rules
sections.content: Universal negative and particular affirmative propositions convert simply. Universal affirmative converts partially.

sections.title: The Tool for Science
sections.content: The Prior Analytics provides the formal machinery used in Posterior Analytics for scientific demonstration.

funFacts: Invented formal logic - dominated for 2000 years
The word 'logic' comes from Aristotle's 'organon' (tool)
His system was complete but limited compared to modern logic
Medieval logicians developed his system extensively

keyPrinciples.explanation: The middle term connects major and minor terms in the conclusion
The position of middle term determines the figure and valid moods
All valid syllogisms can be reduced to first figure moods

title: Generation of Animals
subtitle: The Science of Reproduction
summary: Aristotle's detailed study of animal reproduction, heredity, and embryonic development.
keyConcept: The male provides the form, the female provides the matter
keyConceptExplanation: In reproduction, semen provides the formal and efficient cause, menstrual blood provides the material cause

sections.title: Theory of Reproduction
sections.content: Male provides movement and form through semen. Female provides matter through menstrual blood. The male is active principle, female passive.

sections.title: Embryonic Development
sections.content: Detailed observations of chick embryo development. Argued for epigenesis - gradual formation of parts - against preformation.

sections.title: Heredity and Resemblance
sections.content: Proposed pangenesis theory - semen contains representations from all body parts. Explained inheritance and atavism.

sections.title: Spontaneous Generation
sections.content: Believed some creatures (insects, worms) arise spontaneously from decaying matter under influence of sun's heat.

funFacts: Based on dissection of many animals
His theory of reproduction was accepted until 19th century
The 'female as mutilated male' concept is notoriously sexist
His embryology was remarkably accurate given his tools

keyPrinciples.explanation: Embryos develop toward their natural ends - the adult form
Nutritive soul appears first, then perceptive, in embryonic development
The female contributes the material substrate for development

title: Parts of Animals
subtitle: The Teleology of Biological Structures
summary: Aristotle's analysis of animal anatomy and the functional purposes of biological structures.
keyConceptExplanation: Every part of an organism exists for a purpose that contributes to the whole

sections.title: Functional Analysis
sections.content: Each part exists for a function: eyes for seeing, hearts for pumping blood. Understanding parts requires understanding their purposes.

sections.title: Comparative Anatomy
sections.content: Compared similar parts across species: teeth in different animals, digestive systems, respiratory organs. Noted homologous structures.

sections.title: Material and Formal Causes
sections.content: Explained why animals have the parts they do by both material necessity and formal/functional requirements.

sections.title: The Priority of Form
sections.content: The organism's form determines what parts it has, not vice versa. The whole is prior to the parts.

funFacts: Founded comparative anatomy as a science
His teleological approach dominated biology until Darwin
Made many accurate observations despite limited tools
Classified animals by their essential characteristics

keyPrinciples.explanation: The needs of the organism determine what parts it develops
Parts are organized into systems serving the whole organism
Some features arise from material necessity, others serve clear purposes

title: History of Animals
subtitle: The Encyclopedia of Animal Life
summary: Aristotle's massive compilation of observations about animal behavior, anatomy, and classification.
keyConceptExplanation: Systematic collection and organization of facts about animals based on observation

sections.title: Comprehensive Scope
sections.content: Described over 500 species: mammals, birds, fish, insects, reptiles. Covered anatomy, reproduction, behavior, habitats.

sections.title: Behavioral Observations
sections.content: Detailed accounts of mating habits, feeding, migration, social behavior. Noted tool use in some animals.

sections.title: Classification System
sections.content: Grouped animals by shared characteristics: blooded vs bloodless, live-bearing vs egg-laying, locomotion methods.

sections.title: Methodological Approach
sections.content: Collected reports from fishermen, hunters, farmers. Critically evaluated sources. Emphasized direct observation.

funFacts: Largest biological work from antiquity
Some observations weren't confirmed until 19th century
Mixed accurate observations with folklore and errors
Influenced zoology until the Renaissance

keyPrinciples.explanation: Biological science must begin with collection of facts
Facts must be organized by meaningful categories
Reports must be evaluated for reliability

title: On Interpretation
subtitle: The Philosophy of Language
summary: Aristotle's analysis of language, truth, and meaning, focusing on propositions and their relationship to reality.
keyConceptExplanation: A statement that affirms or denies something of something and is either true or false

sections.title: Language and Reality
sections.content: Spoken words symbolize mental experiences, which are likenesses of actual things. Language maps onto reality through mental representations.

sections.title: Truth and Falsity
sections.content: Truth is saying of what is that it is, or of what is not that it is not. Falsity is the opposite.

sections.title: The Square of Opposition
sections.content: Relations between categorical propositions: contraries, subcontraries, contradictories, subalterns.

sections.title: Future Contingents
sections.content: Famous 'sea-battle' problem: Are statements about future contingent events true or false now? Suggested they are neither yet.

funFacts: Introduced the square of opposition used in logic for centuries
The 'sea-battle' problem remains debated in philosophy of time
His theory of truth influenced the correspondence theory
Work heavily influenced medieval philosophy of language

keyPrinciples.explanation: Truth consists in correspondence between statements and reality
Every proposition must be true or false
Language connects to reality through mental representations

title: Eudemian Ethics
subtitle: The Alternative Ethical System
summary: Aristotle's other major work on ethics, with different emphases and organization than the Nicomachean Ethics.
keyConcept: The contemplative life as highest happiness
keyConceptExplanation: The life of philosophical contemplation is the most divine and self-sufficient form of happiness

sections.title: The Three Lives
sections.content: Examines life of pleasure, political life, and contemplative life. Concludes contemplative life is best.

sections.title: Virtue and the Divine
sections.content: Stronger emphasis on connection between human virtue and divine activity. Contemplation imitates God's activity.

sections.title: The Role of Fortune
sections.content: Discusses how external goods and luck affect happiness. The virtuous person makes best use of any circumstances.

sections.title: Friendship and Self-Sufficiency
sections.content: Explores how friendship complements rather than compromises self-sufficiency.

funFacts: Named after Aristotle's student Eudemus
Relationship to Nicomachean Ethics is debated by scholars
Some think it's earlier, some think it's later
Less studied but contains important differences

keyPrinciples.explanation: Theoretical contemplation is the highest human activity
Humans have a divine element (nous) that enables contemplation
Some external goods are necessary for full happiness

title: Constitution of the Athenians
subtitle: Political History and Analysis
summary: Aristotle's historical analysis of Athenian constitutional development, the only surviving work from his collection of 158 constitutions.
keyConceptExplanation: Political systems develop through historical stages reflecting social and economic changes

sections.title: Historical Development
sections.content: Traces Athenian constitution from monarchy through aristocracy, tyranny, to democracy. Analyzes causes of constitutional changes.

sections.title: Institutional Analysis
sections.content: Describes Athenian political institutions: Assembly, Council, courts, magistrates. Explains their functions and powers.

sections.title: Social Context
sections.content: Connects constitutional changes to class struggles between aristocrats, farmers, merchants, and the poor.

sections.title: Critical Assessment
sections.content: Evaluates strengths and weaknesses of Athenian democracy. Criticizes radical democracy while acknowledging its achievements.

funFacts: Only one of 158 constitutions to survive complete
Rediscovered on Egyptian papyrus in 1890
Confirmed Aristotle's authorship of the constitutions project
Major source for Athenian political history

keyPrinciples.explanation: Understand constitutions through their historical development
Constitutions reflect underlying social and economic structures
Constitutions tend to change in predictable patterns

title: On Philosophy
subtitle: The Lost Dialogue
summary: Aristotle's lost dialogue criticizing Plato's Theory of Forms and developing his own metaphysical alternative.
keyConceptExplanation: Systematic arguments against the existence of separate Platonic Forms

sections.title: The Third Man Argument
sections.content: If a Form exists because particulars share a quality, there must be a higher Form for what the Form and particulars share, leading to infinite regress.

sections.title: Arguments from the Sciences
sections.content: Mathematics and other sciences don't require separate Forms. They study physical objects qua mathematical properties.

sections.title: The Argument from Relatives
sections.content: If there's a Form of 'the Equal,' it must be equal to something. But Forms can't be related to particulars.

sections.title: Development of Alternative
sections.content: Began developing his own concepts of substance, form-in-matter, and the Unmoved Mover as alternatives to Platonic Forms.

funFacts: Known only through fragments quoted by later authors
Marked Aristotle's break from Platonism
The 'Third Man' argument remains influential in metaphysics
Shows Aristotle's philosophical development

keyPrinciples.explanation: Forms exist in particular things, not separately
Good explanations don't generate infinite chains
Metaphysics must be grounded in observable reality

title: Protrepticus
subtitle: Exhortation to Philosophy
summary: Aristotle's popular work urging the value of philosophical life, known only through fragments and quotations.
keyConceptExplanation: To argue against philosophy is itself to philosophize, so one must philosophize

sections.title: The Opening Argument
sections.content: One must either philosophize or not philosophize. But to choose not to philosophize requires philosophical reasoning. Therefore, one must philosophize.

sections.title: The Value of Contemplation
sections.content: Philosophical contemplation is the most pleasant, virtuous, and self-sufficient activity. It actualizes what is highest in human nature.

sections.title: Philosophy vs Practical Arts
sections.content: While practical arts serve necessary ends, philosophy serves the highest end - understanding for its own sake. It liberates us from mere utility.

sections.title: The Philosophical Life
sections.content: The life of philosophy is the most divine life available to humans, allowing us to participate in the eternal and universal.

funFacts: Means 'exhortation' or 'persuasion' in Greek
Was Aristotle's most popular work in antiquity
Known only through quotations in later authors like Iamblichus
Influenced many to pursue philosophical life
More Platonic in tone than his later works

keyPrinciples.explanation: Philosophy is unavoidable for rational beings
Theoretical life is superior to practical life
Knowledge is valuable for its own sake, not just utility

title: On Generation and Corruption
subtitle: The Theory of Change
summary: Aristotle's analysis of substantial change - how things come into being and pass away.
keyConceptExplanation: Generation/corruption involve new substances; alteration involves changes in existing substances

sections.title: Types of Change
sections.content: Distinguishes generation/corruption (substantial change) from alteration (qualitative change), growth (quantitative change), and locomotion (change of place).

sections.title: The Four Elements
sections.content: All sublunary bodies composed of earth, water, air, fire. Each characterized by two primary qualities: hot/cold, wet/dry.

sections.title: The Process of Mixture
sections.content: True mixture isn't just juxtaposition but fusion where ingredients are potentially present but actually form a new substance.

sections.title: Contact and Action
sections.content: For change to occur, agent and patient must be in contact and have contrasting qualities (hot acts on cold, etc.).

funFacts: Provided the chemical theory for 2000 years
His element theory influenced alchemy and early chemistry
Rejected atomism in favor of continuum theory
Distinguished chemical from physical changes

keyPrinciples.explanation: Elements can change into one another by quality alteration
All action requires contact between agent and patient
Elemental differences are qualitative, not just quantitative

title: Magna Moralia
subtitle: The Great Ethics
summary: A shorter work on ethics likely compiled by Aristotle's students, summarizing his ethical views.
keyConceptExplanation: Moral virtue is a state of character concerned with choice, lying in the mean relative to us

sections.title: Summary of Ethics
sections.content: Covers same topics as Nicomachean Ethics: happiness, virtue, friendship, but in more condensed and sometimes different form.

sections.title: The Definition of Virtue
sections.content: Virtue is a state of the soul that chooses the mean relative to us, defined by reason as the prudent person would define it.

sections.title: Practical Wisdom
sections.content: Emphasizes the role of practical wisdom (phronesis) in determining the mean in particular situations.

sections.title: Friendship Types
sections.content: Discusses the three types of friendship but with slightly different emphasis and examples.

funFacts: Most scholars doubt Aristotle wrote it himself
Probably student notes or compilation
Shorter and less sophisticated than other ethical works
Useful for seeing how Aristotle's teaching was transmitted

keyPrinciples.explanation: Likely represents how students understood and transmitted Aristotle's teaching
Presents Aristotle's ethics in more accessible form
May have been used as introductory text for students

title: On Breath
subtitle: The Physiology of Respiration
summary: Aristotle's analysis of respiration and its role in vital functions across different types of animals.
keyConceptExplanation: Breath or pneuma is the carrier of vital heat and soul functions in living organisms

sections.title: Comparative Respiration
sections.content: Analyzes how different animals breathe: lungs, gills, tracheae, or through skin. Relates respiratory methods to habitat and anatomy.

sections.title: Vital Heat Theory
sections.content: Respiration serves to cool the innate heat of living organisms. The heart is the source of this vital heat.

sections.title: Pneuma and Soul Functions
sections.content: Breath (pneuma) carries psychic functions. It's the instrument of the soul for movement and sensation.

sections.title: Embryological Development
sections.content: Discusses how respiratory systems develop in embryos and their connection to cardiovascular systems.

funFacts: His theory of pneuma influenced later vitalist theories
Correctly identified heart as central to circulation
Made detailed observations of fish gills and insect tracheae
Connected respiration with temperature regulation

keyPrinciples.explanation: Living organisms maintain innate heat that requires regulation
Respiratory systems adapt to organisms' environments and needs
Pneuma serves as the soul's instrument for bodily functions

title: Economics
subtitle: Household Management
summary: Work on household and estate management, likely by Aristotle's students rather than himself.
keyConceptExplanation: Household management for the good life vs wealth-getting for its own sake

sections.title: Household Management
sections.content: The art of managing household resources for the good life. Includes relations between husband-wife, parent-child, master-slave.

sections.title: Wealth Acquisition
sections.content: Distinguishes natural wealth-getting (for household needs) from unnatural (money-making for its own sake).

sections.title: The Four Types of Economy
sections.content: Royal, provincial, city, and individual household management. Each has its own principles and challenges.

sections.title: Practical Advice
sections.content: Provides practical advice for estate management, agriculture, and household organization.

funFacts: Probably not by Aristotle himself
Reflects conventional Greek views on household management
Source for understanding ancient Greek domestic life
Origin of word 'economics' (oikonomia = household management)

keyPrinciples.explanation: Wealth should be limited to what's needed for the good life
Some forms of wealth-getting are natural, others unnatural
The household is the fundamental economic unit
